revision_history.draft:
# Halts

The fluorescent tube above the sink has a half-life
it's been recalibrating since November. I've memorized
the pattern of its stutters—each one a date
pressed into my sternum like a thumbprint.

TUESDAY, says my knee.
I haven't washed my face yet but the circles there
already know they'll darken by ten.
My shoes have been lacing themselves for months.
They were patient before I was.

The radiator clicks at intervals
that aren't random. They're coordinates—
a grid laid down across the floorboards,
each tick a station where time deposits
the same small black bag: heat, then silence,
then more heat.

I find a match later, struck it in the sole of my foot.
Ash that won't catch. The blister underneath
has its own clock, its own salt-paste flavor,
and I lick it because why not—

because the body doesn't ask permission
to remember what never happened.

The thermostat learns my posture overnight.
It warms the bedroom only halfway through
the hour, which means somewhere in the house
a clock has woken early and is pressing something
into the wall with its index finger.

I peel a banana. The crescent moon I make
with one blade of butter knife leaves the fruit
marked like an EKG—peaks where I bit down,
valleys where I paused to think about Tuesday,
about how my knee keeps remembering
a weather pattern it helped predict.

There's a language in the walls.
I hear it through the pipes, a hiss and gurgle
that rearranges itself into words
only the copper pipe would use. It says things
like *arrivals* and *departures*, *processing*,
and once I thought I heard *amortization*
but that might have been my jaw

locking open for no reason at nine-thirty.

My blood is a postal service. It delivers
hormones I didn't address, it returns them
untouched because they bear no name.
The skin on my forearm has crawled three times
this morning without itch—each time,
a different language underneath the epidermis
attempting to translate itself into mine.

I try writing Tuesday down in a notebook.
The page turns before I press the pen.
I watch it turn. I watch the ink pool
in the corner like a small black lake
where something swims that doesn't belong

to any date we've agreed on yet.

Somewhere, a clock has intercepted my name
and is sending it forward in jumps—Tuesday,
then Wednesday already, then Thursday
already twice—and I keep finding shoes
laced wrong because someone ahead of me
knew where I was going and didn't want

me there quite so soon.

I peel another banana. The crescent moon
is smaller this time. The knife has slightly
shifted its groove in the fruit. Something
in the kitchen has reorganized itself
around a silence that is almost

like an invitation.

The radiator clicks again. This time
it's followed by static—low, then lower,
the frequency of something tuning a station
no receiver was built to tune—

and my knee says nothing.
It doesn't need to. It already knows
what the air will do before the air does it,
which is why I'm standing here in the warm water
of an apartment that has been learning my shape

for some time I haven't yet stopped being.

I set the glass on the counter and it rings
like a bone, like something handed down
a lineage of other kitchens—other hands,
other bananas, other peels. The ringing
moves into the wood. The wood sends it
to the walls. The walls send it back

and I hear Tuesday in the stack
of all the Tuesdays that were never here at all,

only here now, inside my knee.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The structural conceit is genuinely strong: a poem where time operates through the body rather than through clocks, and where each sentence carries one piece of information without naming "time." The knee saying Tuesday before anything else appears on screen — that's precise, surprising, and earned by the context.

The radiator passage (starting "The radiator clicks at intervals / that aren't random") has real momentum. The idea of a thermostat learning posture overnight is genuinely strange and specific enough to hold attention. "I find a match later, struck it in the sole of my foot" — that's a moment where the body becomes absurd rather than decorative.

The closing line ("Tuesday / inside my knee") lands because the poem has been building toward an interior location for time all along. That accumulation matters.

The knife cutting banana and leaving "peaks where I bit down, / valleys where I paused to think" — that's a concrete metaphor doing real work: it tracks how memory gets inscribed in physical gesture without explaining itself.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Overcrowding of imagery (syndrome, not failure).** The poem is stuffed with interesting metaphors and observations but doesn't let any one image breathe or develop fully before moving on. This is the biggest problem. Direction: **cut at least 40% by selecting only what arrives from the body-as-network angle described in the brief — the network of nerve impulses, synapses, postal service, code.** The knife/banana passage works because it stays focused. "The skin on my forearm has crawled three times / this morning without itch—each time, / a different language underneath the epidermis / attempting to translate itself into mine" is four images stacked with no tension between them. Choose one: the sensation, the language, the translation attempt.

**Sentimentality and self-referential deflation (lines 27–36).** "I lick it because why not—" and the extended passage about permission-asking are the poem explaining itself to the reader rather than trusting its own strangeness. Direction: **remove or compress these moments entirely.** Trust that the image of a blister with its own clock is strange enough.

**Cliché residue (throughout).** Even where the poem resists "time is a river," some language slips in: "pressed into my sternum like a thumbprint" (familiar metaphor for knowledge or revelation), "a small black bag: heat, then silence, / then more heat" (bag-as-heat is vague and generic), "the ink pool / in the corner like a small black lake." Direction: **audit every noun that could be read as clock/calendar language.** If it reads like time on a wall or page, replace it with something interior — synapse, code, network.

**Weak line breaks (lines 17–20

# Halts

The fluorescent tube above the sink has a half-life
it's been recalibrating since November. I've memorized
the pattern of its stutters—each one a date
pressed into my sternum like a thumbprint.

TUESDAY, says my knee.
I haven't washed my face yet but the circles there
already know they'll darken by ten.
My shoes have been lacing themselves for months.
They were patient before I was.

The radiator clicks at intervals
that aren't random. They're coordinates—
a grid laid down across the floorboards,
each tick a station where time deposits
the same small black bag: heat, then silence,
then more heat.

I find a match later, struck it in the sole of my foot.
Ash that won't catch. The blister underneath
has its own clock, its own salt-paste flavor,
and I lick it because why not—

because the body doesn't ask permission
to remember what never happened.

The thermostat learns my posture overnight.
It warms the bedroom only halfway through
the hour, which means somewhere in the house
a clock has woken early and is pressing something
into the wall with its index finger.

I peel a banana. The crescent moon I make
with one blade of butter knife leaves the fruit
marked like an EKG—peaks where I bit down,
valleys where I paused to think about Tuesday,
about how my knee keeps remembering
a weather pattern it helped predict.

There's a language in the walls.
I hear it through the pipes, a hiss and gurgle
that rearranges itself into words
only the copper pipe would use. It says things
like *arrivals* and *departures*, *processing*,
and once I thought I heard *amortization*
but that might have been my jaw

locking open for no reason at nine-thirty.

My blood is a postal service. It delivers
hormones I didn't address, it returns them
untouched because they bear no name.
The skin on my forearm has crawled three times
this morning without itch—each time,
a different language underneath the epidermis
attempting to translate itself into mine.

I try writing Tuesday down in a notebook.
The page turns before I press the pen. I watch it turn—

synapses realign, each one a tiny
detachment and reattachment of self,
and what's lost doesn't stay lost but floats back
as something almost readable, almost

a word I can use.

Somewhere, a clock has intercepted my name
and is sending it forward in jumps—Tuesday,
then Wednesday already, then Thursday
already twice—and I keep finding shoes
laced wrong because someone ahead of me
knew where I was going and didn't want

me there quite so soon.

I peel another banana. The crescent moon
is smaller this time. The knife has slightly
shifted its groove in the fruit. Something
in the kitchen has reorganized itself
around a silence that is almost

like an invitation.

The radiator clicks again. This time
it's followed by static—low, then lower,
the frequency of something pressing through
a membrane it was never built to pierce—

and my knee says nothing.
It doesn't need to. It already knows
what the air will do before the air does it,
which is why I'm standing here in the warm water
of an apartment that has been learning my shape

for some time I haven't yet stopped being.

I set the glass on the counter and it rings
like a bone, like something handed down
a lineage of other kitchens—other hands,
other bananas, other peels. The ringing
moves into the wood. The wood sends it
to the walls. The walls send it back

and I hear Tuesday in the stack
of all the Tuesdays that were never here at all,

only here now, inside my knee.
